Data.event_text: 1 January  A visit by Thor the Walrus to Scarborough harbour, North Yorkshire overnight on New Year's Eve results in the town's New Year fireworks celebrations being cancelled to let the walrus rest for his journey to the Arctic. He was previously spotted at Pagham Harbour, Calshot, Hampshire in December 2022.
Three people are killed by a fire at the New County Hotel in Perth, Scotland.

Data.event_text: 6 January  COVID-19 in the UK Almost three million people were infected with COVID-19 over the Christmas period (the highest since July 2022), the  latest Office for National Statistics data suggests, with one in 20 having the virus in England, one in 18 in Wales, one in 25 in Scotland and one in 16 in Northern Ireland. XBB.1.5, the new Omicron variant of the virus, is believed to be responsible for one in 200 infections in the UK.

Data.event_text: The ONS reports that inflation dropped for the second month running, to 10.5% in December, from 10.7% the previous month. At the two extremes of the ONS's list of "notable movements" that contribute to the overall figure, 'clothing and footwear' price inflation dropped from 7.5% to 6.4%, 'furniture and household goods' dropped from 10.8% to 9.8%, 'food and non-alcoholic beverages' rose from 16.5% to 16.9%, and 'restaurants and hotels' rose from 10.2% to 11.4%.

links.text: -"UK inflation dips slightly to 10.5% but people continue to feel pinch". The Guardian. 18 January 2023. Retrieved 18 January 2023.-

Data.event_text: William Shawcross, the Commissioner for Public Appointments, begins a review into the process of hiring Chairman of the BBC Richard Sharp following allegations he helped then-PM Boris Johnson secure a loan guarantee shortly before his appointment. Johnson dismisses the claims, saying Sharp had no knowledge of his finances. Sharp says that although he contacted Cabinet Secretary Simon Case in December 2020 about the offer of a loan to Johnson, he was not involved in discussions.

Data.event_text: 1 February  An estimated 475,000 workers go on strike, the single biggest day of industrial action for more than a decade, in disputes over pay and conditions. This includes 200,000 teachers, 100,000 civil servants including border force workers, university lecturers, security guards, and train drivers. The government warns the public to expect "significant disruption".

links.text: -"Millions face disruption as strikes hit schools, trains, universities and border checks – live". The Guardian. 1 February 2023. Retrieved 1 February 2023.-

Data.event_text: COVID-19 in the UK Lockdown Files The Daily Telegraph publishes more of Matt Hancock's WhatsApp exchanges, this time with former education secretary Gavin Williamson in December 2020, when a debate into whether schools should reopen following the Christmas holiday was taking place. The leaked messages suggest Hancock favoured school closures, while Williamson was more hesitant. Hancock, who worked alongside journalist Isabel Oakeshott to co-author a book, describes the release of the messages as a "massive betrayal and breach of trust". In response, Oakeshott says she released the messages because she believed doing so was in the "public interest".

Data.event_text: Dominic Raab resigns as deputy prime minister after the inquiry finds he acted in an "intimidating" and "insulting" manner with civil servants. Raab subsequently criticises what he describes as "activist civil servants" attempting to block the work of government.

Data.event_text: 2023 United Kingdom local elections The Conservatives incur significant losses, while Labour and the Lib Dems gain control of a number of councils from the Conservatives. The Green Party also make record gains, with over 200 councillors, and win majority control of Mid Suffolk District Council, the party's first ever council majority. The UK Independence Party, which had 500 council seats in 2014, loses the remainder of its councillors.

Data.event_text: 5 May  Following the first conviction for trafficking for the purposes of organ removal in England and Wales, Nigerian senator Ike Ekweremadu is sentenced to nine years and eight months in prison after bringing a young street trader to the UK in order to procure his kidney for a transplant. The senator's wife and a doctor who also assisted in the plan are also sent to prison.

Data.event_text: House of Commons Speaker Sir Lindsay Hoyle unveils two new stained glass windows at the Palace of Westminster. One featuring his new personal coat of arms, with a rugby league ball, bees and Lancashire roses. The other window celebrates Britain's Coat of Arms of all three Crown Dependencies and all sixteen British Overseas Territories. Hoyle said at the unveiling the windows were and "will forever be tangible reminders of the strong, close links between the United Kingdom, the overseas territories and the crown dependencies".

links.text: -"Commons Speaker Sir Lindsay Hoyle's coat of arms revealed". BBC News. 9 May 2023. Retrieved 9 February 2024.-

Data.event_text: Wind power is reported as the main source of electricity generation in the UK for the first three months of the year, overtaking gas.

Data.event_text: Defence Secretary Ben Wallace confirms that the UK will supply Storm Shadow cruise missiles to Ukraine, to assist the country in repelling the Russian invasion. These have a much longer range (250 km/155 mi) than US-supplied HIMARS missiles (80 km/50 mi).

Data.event_text: The final of the 2023 Eurovision Song Contest takes place in Liverpool. Data.event_text: Nadine Dorries announces she will stand down as Conservative MP for Mid Bedfordshire with immediate effect, triggering a by-election. On 14  she said that she had submitted a subject access request to the House of Lords Appointments Commission (HOLAC) and was waiting to resign until she had received all unredacted "WhatsApps, text messages, all emails and minutes of meetings" related to why she was denied a peerage. Dorries eventually resigns on 26 August., 78 days after her initial announcement of "immediate effect".

Data.event_text: Boris Johnson's Resignation Honours are published. Highlights include knighthoods for Jacob Rees-Mogg and Simon Clarke, and a damehood for Priti Patel. The decision to award a life peerage to former special adviser Charlotte Owen is criticised due to her young age (29) and perceived lack of experience or contributions to British society.

links.text: -Nevett, Joshua (9 June 2023). "Boris Johnson rewards key allies in resignation honours list". BBC News. Retrieved 9 June 2023.-
-"Honours row grows after claim Charlotte Owen 'worked as maternity cover'". The Guardian. 18 June 2023. Retrieved 12 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: Johnson announces he will stand down as an MP with immediate effect after receiving the Commons Select Committee of Privileges's report into the Partygate scandal, triggering a by-election.

links.text: -"Boris Johnson steps down as MP with immediate effect". BBC News. 9 June 2023. Retrieved 9 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: Nigel Adams becomes the third Conservative MP in quick succession to stand down from Parliament with immediate effect, triggering a by-election.

links.text: -"Boris Johnson ally Nigel Adams to stand down as MP with 'immediate effect' triggering third by-election". Sky News. 10 June 2023. Retrieved 10 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: Temperatures reach above 30 °C for the first time since 24 August 2022, marking the hottest day of the year so far. Three guardsmen collapse during a military parade in London, due to the heat.

links.text: -"Guardsmen faint as UK temperatures hit 30C for first time this year". The Guardian. 10 June 2023. Retrieved 10 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: Manchester City beat Inter Milan in the 2023 UEFA Champions League Final 10, with Rodri scoring the only goal to win the UEFA Champions League for the first time in their history. They become the second English team ever to win the Continental Treble after Manchester United in the 1998-99 Manchester United F.C. season, winning the FA Cup and the Premier League alongside the UEFA Champions League.

links.text: -"Man City Claim Treble With Champions League win". BBC Sport.-

Data.event_text: Energy Secretary Grant Shapps, speaking on Sunday with Laura Kuenssberg, declares that the country "wants to move on" from Boris Johnson and dismisses claims the ex-PM was the victim of a "witch hunt".

links.text: -"Country wants to move on from Boris Johnson, says Shapps". BBC News. 11 June 2023. Retrieved 11 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: Police Scotland arrest Scotland's former First Minister, Nicola Sturgeon, as part of their ongoing investigation into the SNP's finances. She is subsequently released without charge.

links.text: -"Nicola Sturgeon arrested in SNP finances inquiry". BBC News. 11 June 2023. Retrieved 11 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: Following a period of hot weather, thunderstorms and torrential rain bring flash flooding to parts of the UK.

links.text: -Slow, Oliver; Rhoden-Paul, Andre (12 June 2023). "Storms bring flash flooding and travel disruption". BBC News. Retrieved 12 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: A mother-of-three is sentenced to 28 months in prison for inducing an abortion at home during 2020 with medication while she was 3234 weeks pregnant. The medication was obtained following a remote consultation at which the woman misled doctors over the advancement of her pregnancy.

links.text: -Collins, Riyah (12 June 2023). "Mother jailed for taking abortion pills after legal limit". BBC News. Retrieved 12 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: 2023 Nottingham attacks A major incident is declared in Nottingham, with much of the city centre cordoned off, following a vehicle-ramming and knife attack. A 31-year-old man is arrested on suspicion of multiple murders, following the deaths of three people including two university students, while three others are hospitalised.

links.text: -"Man held after three found dead in Nottingham city centre". BBC News. 13 June 2023. Retrieved 13 June 2023.-
-"Nottingham: three people dead and three in hospital after 'major incident' – latest updates". The Guardian. 13 June 2023. Retrieved 13 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: The first day of a public inquiry into the COVID-19 pandemic begins in central London. The inquiry's lead lawyer says "very little thought" was given about the impact of a national lockdown and that Brexit planning may have occupied too much of the government's time and resources, while a counsel for the Covid-19 Bereaved Families for Justice accuses the authorities of being "complacent".

links.text: -"UK complacent over Covid pandemic planning – families' lawyer". BBC News. 13 June 2023. Retrieved 13 June 2023.-
-"UK Covid inquiry: government accused of giving 'very little' advance thought to lockdown and being too focused on flu – live". The Guardian. 13 June 2023. Retrieved 13 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: A heatwave is declared in several parts of the UK as temperatures reach 30 °C, and after exceeding 25 °C for three consecutive days; the UK's heat-health alert is also extended.

links.text: -Russell, Rachel (13 June 2023). "UK weather: Parts of UK officially in heatwave". BBC News. Retrieved 14 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: Vodafone and Three announce a merger, pending approval from regulators, to create the largest mobile company in the UK.

links.text: -"Vodafone Three deal to create UK's largest mobile firm". BBC News. 14 June 2023. Retrieved 14 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: Thousands of people gather for a vigil to mourn the victims of the attacks in Nottingham. Police continue questioning a suspect, as the BBC obtains CCTV footage of a man believed to be the perpetrator.

links.text: -"Thousands gather to mourn victims at Nottingham vigil". BBC News. 14 June 2023. Retrieved 14 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: Researchers at the University of Cambridge report the creation of the first synthetic human embryo from stem cells, without the need for sperm or egg cells.

links.text: -Devlin, Hannah (14 June 2023). "Synthetic human embryos created in groundbreaking advance". The Guardian. Retrieved 14 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: Partygate A 13-month investigation by the House of Commons' Privileges Committee concludes that ex-Prime Minister Johnson deliberately misled the Commons over gatherings during pandemic restrictions at 10 Downing Street and Chequers. The report proposes that he would be suspended for 90 days if still an MP. It states that he deliberately misled the House and the committee, impugned the committee and was "complicit in the campaign of abuse and attempted intimidation of the Committee".

links.text: -"Johnson faced 90-day suspension for deliberately misleading MPs over Partygate". BBC News. 15 June 2023. Retrieved 15 June 2023.-
-"Boris Johnson deliberately misled MPs over Partygate and faced 90-day ban before he quit, report finds – UK politics live". The Guardian. 15 June 2023. Retrieved 15 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: The Parole Board announces that double child killer and rapist Colin Pitchfork has been granted parole and will be released from prison. Alberto Costa, MP for South Leicestershire where the girls were killed, writes to the Justice Secretary to seek "an immediate and urgent review" of the decision.

links.text: -"Colin Pitchfork: Double child killer and rapist to be released". BBC News. 15 June 2023. Retrieved 15 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: A hosepipe and sprinkler ban is announced for Kent and Sussex, beginning on 26 June, after water demand hits record levels.

links.text: -"Kent and Sussex hosepipe ban announced from 26 June". BBC News. 16 June 2023. Retrieved 16 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: The Ministry of Justice confirms that serial killer Levi Bellfield, who is serving two whole life sentences for murder, will be allowed to marry his girlfriend in prison as there are no legal restrictions preventing him from doing so.

links.text: -Crew, Jemma (16 June 2023). "Serial killer Levi Bellfield can marry in prison". BBC News. Retrieved 16 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: Boris Johnson breaks the Ministerial Code for a second time, by not asking advice from the Advisory Committee on Business Appointments before accepting a new job writing for the Daily Mail. The previous time was shortly after he stood down as foreign secretary in , when he accepted a similar job with the Daily Telegraph.

links.text: -"Boris Johnson breaks ministerial code with new Daily Mail job". BBC News. 16 June 2023. Retrieved 16 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: A 31-year-old man is charged with three counts of murder and three of attempted murder following the Nottingham attacks.

links.text: -"Nottingham attacks: Valdo Calocane charged with three counts of murder". BBC News. 16 June 2023. Retrieved 16 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: David Warburton, the MP for Somerton and Frome, becomes the fourth Conservative MP in eight days to announce their resignation from the House of Commons, doing so following his suspension from the party over allegations of sexual misconduct, and triggering a by-election in his constituency.

links.text: -Rhoden-Paul, Andre; Kelly, Chris (18 June 2023). "David Warburton quits as MP, triggering another by-election". BBC News. Retrieved 18 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: The 2023 Trooping the Colour ceremony takes place.

links.text: -"Trooping the Colour: Royals celebrate King Charles's first birthday parade". BBC News. 17 June 2023. Retrieved 17 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: 18 June  Partygate The Mirror publishes video footage of a party held in December 2020 at Conservative Party Headquarters. Housing Secretary Michael Gove describes the incident as "indefensible".

links.text: -Adams, Charley; Seddon, Paul (18 June 2023). "Michael Gove says sorry over Tory lockdown party video". BBC News. Retrieved 18 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: 19 June  Partygate MPs back, by 354 votes to seven, a report finding Boris Johnson deliberately misled the Commons over lockdown parties at Downing Street.

links.text: -"MPs approve Boris Johnson Partygate report". BBC News. 19 June 2023. Retrieved 19 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: The Chancellor, Jeremy Hunt, rules out direct financial support for mortgage holders, over fears it would "make inflation worse, not better".

links.text: -"Jeremy Hunt rules out government help on mortgages". BBC News. 20 June 2023. Retrieved 20 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: British businessmen Hamish Harding and Shahzada Dawood, along with Dawood's son, Suleman, are confirmed as being aboard the missing submersible that disappeared during a voyage to see the wreck of the RMS Titanic two days earlier.

links.text: -Jackson, Marie; Davis, Matthew (20 June 2023). "Hamish Harding, Shahzada Dawood and son Suleman: Who is on board Titanic sub?". BBC News. Retrieved 20 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: 21 June  UK inflation figures for May 2023 show it remained higher than expected, at 8.7%.

links.text: -Race, Michael (21 June 2023). "Interest rate rise expected after UK inflation shock". BBC News. Retrieved 21 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: The Bank of England raises the official bank rate from 4.5% to 5%, the 13th consecutive rise, and a greater increase than economists had expected.

links.text: -Thomas, Daniel; Edser, Nick; Islam, Faisal (22 June 2023). "Interest rates: Bank of England governor admits rise painful for many". BBC News. Retrieved 22 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: The RMT announces three fresh days of strike action for 20, 22 and 29 July.

links.text: -"Rail union announces three days of strikes in July". BBC News. 22 June 2023. Retrieved 22 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: Banks and building societies are summoned for a meeting with Jeremy Hunt as pressure grows on them to help people struggling with rising mortgage costs. A series of measures are agreed, offering more flexibility.

links.text: -"Jeremy Hunt meets UK's biggest lenders in effort to quell mortgage crisis". The Guardian. 23 June 2023. Retrieved 23 June 2023.-
-"Mortgages: Banks offer more flexibility to struggling borrowers". BBC News. 23 June 2023. Retrieved 23 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: Junior doctors in England announce a new five-day walkout from 13 to 18 July  the longest strike yet  over pay.

links.text: -"Junior doctors to hold longest strike yet in July". BBC News. 23 June 2023. Retrieved 23 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: Following a trial at Northampton Crown Court, Louis De Zoysa is convicted of the 2020 murder of police sergeant Matt Ratana.

links.text: -"Matiu Ratana: Man guilty of murdering Met Police sergeant". BBC News. 23 June 2023. Retrieved 23 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: 24 June  The UK government holds an emergency COBRA meeting to discuss the Wagner Group rebellion in Russia. Sunak urges both sides to "be responsible and to protect civilians".

links.text: -Kuenssberg, Laura (24 June 2023). "Rishi Sunak's concern over volatile Russia situation". BBC News. Retrieved 24 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: A national technical fault affects the 999 service, meaning emergency services are unable to receive calls for around two hours. The service is fully restored by the evening.

links.text: -"999 calls: Technical glitch fixed for most forces". BBC News. 25 June 2023. Retrieved 25 June 2023.-
-Andersson, Jasmine (26 June 2023). "BT took three hours to report 999 fault, says minister". BBC News. Retrieved 26 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: A spokesman for Sarah, Duchess of York says that she is recovering following surgery for breast cancer at King Edward VII's Hospital a few days earlier.

links.text: -"Duchess of York recovering after breast cancer operation". BBC News. 25 June 2023. Retrieved 25 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: Elton John plays the final UK concert of his farewell tour at Glastonbury 2023, headlining the Pyramid Stage on the festival's final day.

links.text: -Savage, Mark (26 June 2023). "The sun goes down on Elton John's UK touring career with record-breaking Glastonbury set". BBC News. Retrieved 26 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: A two-year BBC investigation into the 1993 murder of Stephen Lawrence identifies a sixth suspect who was not charged at the time and is now deceased.

links.text: -De Simone, Daniel (26 June 2023). "Stephen Lawrence: BBC names new suspect in UK's most notorious racist murder". BBC News. Retrieved 26 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: Banking giant HSBC announces that it will vacate its 45-storey tower at 8 Canada Square in Canary Wharf and establish a smaller headquarters, possibly in the City of London, when its current lease expires in 2027. The move is attributed to an increase in remote work and less need for in-person office work.

links.text: -"HSBC to leave Canary Wharf tower for new world headquarters". BBC News. 26 June 2023. Retrieved 26 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: Prince William and Geri Horner announce the launch of Homewards, a five-year project aimed at reducing the number of homeless people in the UK.

links.text: -"Newport: Prince William and Geri Halliwell launch homeless scheme". BBC News. 26 June 2023. Retrieved 26 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: The National Cancer Research Institute announces that it will be closing, amid concerns over its funding.

links.text: -"NCRI is winding down after 22 remarkable years". National Cancer Research Institute. 26 June 2023. Retrieved 27 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: Boots announces plans to close 300 of its outlets over the next years, saying it will close stores in close proximity to other branches.

links.text: -Dempsey, Jemma (27 June 2023). "Boots to close 300 UK pharmacies over the next year". BBC News. Retrieved 27 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: A report compiled by the Independent Commission for Equity in Cricket (ICEC) says racism, sexism, classism and elitism are "widespread" in English and Welsh cricket.

links.text: -Shemilt, Stephan (27 June 2023). "Equity in Cricket report: Discrimination 'widespread' in English and Welsh cricket". BBC Sport. Retrieved 27 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: Daniel Korski withdraws as the Conservative Party's candidate for the 2024 London mayoral election after being accused of groping by novelist and TV producer Daisy Goodwin.

links.text: -"Daniel Korski pulls out of mayor race after groping claim". BBC News. 28 June 2023. Retrieved 28 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: A BBC News investigation finds that paedophiles are using Stable Diffusion, a piece of artificial intelligence software, to create lifelike images of child sexual abuse, which are then being distributed through platforms such as Patreon.

links.text: -Crawford, Angus; Smith, Tony (28 June 2023). "Illegal trade in AI child sex abuse images exposed". BBC News. Retrieved 28 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: The plan to deport some asylum seekers to Rwanda is ruled unlawful. In a three-judge decision, the court of appeal overturns a high court decision that previously ruled that Rwanda could be considered a safe third country to send refugees.

links.text: -"In blow to Sunak, UK court rules Rwanda deportation plan unlawful". AL Jazeera.-

Data.event_text: Smoke from record-breaking Canadian wildfires is detected in the UK, having drifted thousands of kilometres over the Atlantic.

links.text: -"Satellite images show Canadian wildfire smoke over UK". BBC News. 29 June 2023. Retrieved 29 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: Sunak unveils an NHS workforce plan that aims to address shortages in the health service by increasing the number of training places for nurses and doctors, as well as retaining them in the NHS workforce.

links.text: -Triggle, Nick; Roxby, Philippa (30 June 2023). "Ministers set out plan to train and keep more NHS staff". BBC News. Retrieved 30 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: The Independent Press Standards Organisation rules that a December 2022 column in The Sun newspaper written by Jeremy Clarkson about Meghan, Duchess of Sussex being paraded naked through the streets was sexist, but rejects complaints that it was either discriminatory on the grounds of race, inaccurate, or sought to harass the duchess. Both The Sun and Clarkson had apologised for the piece in December 2022.

links.text: -Bushby, Helen; McIntosh, Steven; Youngs, Ian (30 June 2023). "Jeremy Clarkson's Meghan article was sexist to duchess, press regulator rules". BBC News. Retrieved 30 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: The Foreign Office issues a travel warning for Britons going to France, as major riots grip the country.

links.text: -"Foreign Office warns Britons over travel to France during riots". BBC News. 1 July 2023. Retrieved 1 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: The price cap on energy bills is reduced, with an average yearly domestic gas and electricity bill falling by £426 to £2,074.

links.text: -Peachey, Kevin (1 July 2023). "Energy bills fall as new price cap comes into force". BBC News. Retrieved 1 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: The Public Order Act 2023 comes into effect in England and Wales, giving police greater powers to move environmental protestors who disrupt transport routes.

links.text: -Slow, Oliver (2 July 2023). "Protests: Police powers to stop new tactics come into effect". BBC News. Retrieved 2 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: Co-op Funeralcare announces that resomation, a process that uses potassium hydroxide and water to break down human remains, will be made available for funerals in the UK for the first time later in the year.

links.text: -Petrie, Emma (2 July 2023). "Water cremation: Co-op Funeralcare to be first UK company to offer resomation". BBC News. Retrieved 2 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: Orkney Islands Council begins movements to change its status, looking at options including becoming either a British Crown Dependency, or a British Overseas Territory of the United Kingdom, or a self-governing territory within the Kingdom of Norway or Denmark.

links.text: -"Orkney council to look at proposals to become territory of Norway". BBC News. 2 July 2023. Retrieved 3 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: Train drivers belonging to the ASLEF union at 16 train operators begin a six-day overtime ban, threatening disruption to services.

links.text: -Austin, Katy (2 July 2023). "Rail disruption warning due to six-day train drivers' overtime ban". BBC News. Retrieved 2 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: The Met Office confirms that the UK has experienced its hottest June on record, with June 2023's average temperature of 15.8 °C beating previous records from 1940 and 1976 by 0.9 °C.

links.text: -Rannard, Georgina (3 July 2023). "UK weather: hottest June since records began – Met Office". BBC News. Retrieved 4 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: The average interest rate on a five-year fixed mortgage deal exceeds 6%.

links.text: -"Mortgage rates: Average five-year fix rises above 6%". BBC News. 4 July 2023. Retrieved 4 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: Partygate scandal The Metropolitan Police announces it is reopening its investigation into a lockdown party held at Conservative Party Headquarters in December 2020, as well as an event held at Westminster on 8 December 2020.

links.text: -"Partygate: Police reopen investigation into Tory 'jingle and mingle' event". BBC News. 4 July 2023. Retrieved 4 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: King Charles III is presented with the Honours of Scotland during a ceremony held at Edinburgh's St Giles Cathedral.

links.text: -"King's visit to Scotland to mark coronation confirmed for July". BBC News. 9 June 2023. Retrieved 9 June 2023.-
-"King Charles receives Scottish crown jewels". BBC News. 5 July 2023. Retrieved 5 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: The Ministry of Defence confirms that UK Special Forces are at the centre of a war crimes investigation involving Afghanistan.

links.text: -Gunter, Joel; O'Grady, Hannah (5 July 2023). "Special Forces at centre of Afghanistan war crimes inquiry, MoD confirms". BBC News. Retrieved 5 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: David Black, the chief executive of Ofwat, suggests that water bills are likely to rise in 2025 as water companies seek to cover the cost of improving services.

links.text: -Dempsey, Jemma (5 July 2023). "Water firms planning to raise bills, says regulator". BBC News. Retrieved 5 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: Two children die, while 15 other people are injured after a Land Rover crashes into a primary school in Wimbledon, south-west London. The crash is not treated as terror-related, but the driver is arrested on suspicion of causing death by dangerous driving.

links.text: -"Seven children hurt as Land Rover crashes into Wimbledon school". BBC News. 6 July 2023. Retrieved 6 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: The Parliamentary Commissioner for Standards recommends that MP Chris Pincher be suspended for eight weeks, following an investigation into groping allegations.

links.text: -"Watchdog recommends eight-week suspension for groping MP". BBC News. 6 July 2023. Retrieved 6 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: The government loses a High Court bid to prevent the COVID-19 Inquiry from seeing Boris Johnson's diaries and WhatsApp messages in full.

links.text: -"Covid inquiry should get Johnson's unredacted messages – High Court". BBC News. 6 July 2023. Retrieved 6 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: Wallasey pub shooting Connor Chapman is found guilty of shooting dead 26-year-old Elle Edwards and injuring four others with a submachine gun. Co-defendant Thomas Waring is also found guilty of possessing a prohibited firearm and assisting an offender. The following day, Chapman is sentenced to a minimum of 48 years in prison, and Waring is given a nine-year prison term.

links.text: -"Elle Edwards: Connor Chapman guilty of Christmas Eve pub murder". BBC News. 6 July 2023. Retrieved 6 July 2023.-
-"Elle Edwards' killer to serve minimum 48 years for murder". BBC News. 7 July 2023. Retrieved 7 July 2023.-

links.text: -Dempsey, Jemma (7 July 2023). "House prices fall at fastest rate in 12 years, says Halifax". BBC News. Retrieved 7 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: A man in his 20s, known publicly only as LXB, becomes the first alleged neo-Nazi in the UK to be placed under special government powers for monitoring and controlling suspected terrorists.

links.text: -De Simone, Daniel (7 July 2023). "First alleged neo-Nazi under special terror powers, BBC learns". BBC News. Retrieved 7 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: Data published by the Office for National Statistics indicates one in 20 people surveyed reported running out of food, and being unable to afford to buy more because of rising food prices.
