Data.event_text: The High Court of England and Wales gives its approval to legal challenges against the Home Office by Braintree District Council in Essex and West Lindsey District Council in Lincolnshire over plans to use two former airbases in the areas, Wethersfield Airbase and RAF Scampton, to house asylum seekers.

links.text: -McMenemy, Rachael (14 July 2023). "Airbase asylum plans: High Court gives permission to councils' challenge". BBC News. Retrieved 14 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: The former Manchester City footballer Benjamin Mendy is cleared of raping a woman and attempting to rape another, following a three-week trial at Chester Crown Court.

links.text: -"Ex-Man City footballer Benjamin Mendy found not guilty of rape". BBC News. 14 July 2023. Retrieved 14 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: Abbott Laboratories, producers of the FreeStyle Libre app, used by around 200,000 people with diabetes in the UK, temporarily withdraw the app from the App Store after technical problems with an update caused it to stop working on Apple devices in the UK.

links.text: -Gerken, Tom (14 July 2023). "Anger and fear after popular diabetes app breaks". BBC News. Retrieved 14 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: Just Stop Oil protesters interrupt the first night of the Proms at London's Royal Albert Hall.

links.text: -"Just Stop Oil protesters interrupt the Proms". BBC News. 15 July 2023. Retrieved 15 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: 15 July  The Local Government Association calls for disposable vapes to be banned in England and Wales by 2024, citing their environmental impact and their appeal to children.

links.text: -King, Ben (15 July 2023). "Disposable vapes: Councils call for total ban by 2024". BBC News. Retrieved 15 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: A report from the National Audit Office concludes that the UK government is likely to miss its 2019 target to build 40 new NHS hospitals by 2030.

links.text: -Pym, High; Seddon, Sean (17 July 2023). "Government to miss 40 new hospitals target – watchdog". BBC News. Retrieved 17 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: As train drivers begin a six-day overtime ban, their union, ASLEF, announces a further six day overtime ban from 31 July.

links.text: -"Train strikes: When are they and why are they taking place?". BBC News. 17 July 2023. Retrieved 17 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: A BBC investigation into working conditions at McDonald's has collected together a number of allegations of sexual assault, harassment, bullying and racism.

links.text: -Nanji, Noor; Conway, Zoe; Layhe, Ellie (18 July 2023). "McDonald's workers speak out over sexual abuse claims". BBC News. Retrieved 18 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: A woman sentenced to 28 months imprisonment for illegally obtaining abortion pills in 2020 has her sentence reduced to a 14-month suspended sentence by the Court of Appeal, and will be released from prison.

links.text: -Rack, Susie (18 July 2023). "Carla Foster: Mother jailed over lockdown abortion to be released". BBC News. Retrieved 18 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: The Home Office confirms the release of the first passports issued in King Charles III's name.

links.text: -Coughlan, Sean (18 July 2023). "First British passports issued with King's name". BBC News. Retrieved 18 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: The first British passports are issued featuring King Charles III.

links.text: -"First British passports issued with King's name". BBC News. 19 July 2023. Retrieved 20 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: The UK rate of inflation falls from 8.7% in May to 7.9% in June.

links.text: -Thomas, Daniel; Islam, Faisal; David, Dharshini (19 July 2023). "Interest rates: Big rise less likely after inflation surprise". BBC News. Retrieved 19 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: Rishi Sunak issues an apology for the UK's historical treatment of LGBT people who were dismissed from the military because of their sexuality.

links.text: -Fisher, Megan; Moss, Lauren; Parry, Josh (19 July 2023). "Rishi Sunak apologises to LGBT veterans for past armed forces gay ban". BBC News. Retrieved 19 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: Senior doctors begin a two-day walkout, their first strike in a decade, amid an ongoing dispute over pay.

links.text: -"Senior doctors stage first strike in a decade". BBC News. 20 July 2023. Retrieved 20 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: The Competition and Markets Authority tells supermarkets they must make their food pricing clearer in order to help shoppers make informed decisions about the best deals.

links.text: -Musafer, Shanaz (20 July 2023). "Supermarkets told to make pricing clearer to help shoppers". BBC News. Retrieved 20 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: A University of Oxford study suggests that if heavy meat eaters were to cut some of it out of their diet it would be like removing eight million cars from the road.

links.text: -Ghosh, Pallab (20 July 2023). "Eating less meat 'like taking 8m cars off road'". BBC News. Retrieved 20 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: The first phase of the COVID-19 Inquiry comes to an end, with an interim report expected to be published in 2024.

links.text: -Read, Jim (20 July 2023). "Covid Inquiry: What have we learnt so far?". BBC News. Retrieved 22 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: Uxbridge and South Ruislip The former seat of ex-PM Boris Johnson is held by the Conservatives, but with a significantly reduced majority of 495 votes. The proposed ULEZ expansion by Labour's Sadiq Khan, Mayor of London, is a factor in the result.
Selby and Ainsty Labour takes the formerly safe Conservative seat of Selby and Ainsty. The swing of 23.7% is the largest since 1945.
Somerton and Frome The Liberal Democrats take Somerton and Frome, overturning a Conservative majority of 29.6%.
2223 July  The most successful weekend for UK cinema-going since 2019 is reported, with Oppenheimer and Barbie taking £30m in their box office openings.

links.text: -"'Barbenheimer' sparks biggest UK box office opener since 2019". BBC News. 24 July 2023. Retrieved 24 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: 23 July  The Cabinet Office announces the launch of the Humanitarian Medal for emergency workers and humanitarian relief teams, such as charities, service personnel and health workers.

links.text: -Coughlan, Sean (23 July 2023). "New British Humanitarian Medal to honour UK disaster rescuers". BBC News. Retrieved 23 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: Thousands of Britons begin arriving home from Greece, after being evacuated due to catastrophic wildfires in the region. Travel agency Thomas Cook promises to refund those who booked holidays.

links.text: -"Rhodes fires: Rhodes rescue flights under way as fires continue". BBC News. 24 July 2023. Retrieved 24 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: The Competition and Markets Authority announces an investigation into companies that offer quickie divorces and will writing.

links.text: -McDonald, Charlotte; Hoggan, Karen (24 July 2023). "'Quickie' divorces and will writing to be investigated". BBC News. Retrieved 24 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: Oscar-winning actor Kevin Spacey is cleared of all charges at London's Southwark Crown Court. His trial had included nine charges, with seven counts of sexual assault against four men.

links.text: -"Kevin Spacey found not guilty in sex offences trial". BBC News. 26 July 2023. Retrieved 26 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: The consultation process for the proposed closure of hundreds of ticket offices at train stations in England is extended until 1 September.

links.text: -Rufo, Yasmin; Austin, Katy (26 July 2023). "Rail ticket office mass closure consultation extended". BBC News. Retrieved 26 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: Dame Alison Rose admits to being the source of an inaccurate BBC news report about Nigel Farage's Coutts bank account after discussing the matter with BBC business editor Simon Jack, something she describes as a "serious error of judgement". She subsequently resigns from her post early the next day.

links.text: -"Nigel Farage: NatWest boss admits 'serious' error in bank closure row". BBC News. 25 July 2023. Retrieved 25 July 2023.-
-Espiner, Tom; Ertl, Michael (26 July 2023). "Nigel Farage says more NatWest bosses must go in Coutts row". BBC News. Retrieved 26 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: The Met Office publishes its State of the UK Climate 2022 report. It concludes that the 40 °C heatwave was "extraordinary", but would be considered an average year by 2060 and a cool year by 2100, if current emission trends continue.

links.text: -"Climate change: Last year's UK heatwave 'a sign of things to come'". BBC News. 27 July 2023. Retrieved 27 July 2023.-
-"Record breaking 2022 indicative of future UK climate". The Met Office. 27 July 2023. Retrieved 27 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: 26-year-old Louis De Zoysa is sentenced to a whole life order for the murder of police officer Matt Ratana in 2020.

links.text: -"Man who shot dead Met police officer given whole life sentence". BBC News. 27 July 2023. Retrieved 27 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: Peter Flavel resigns as chief executive of Coutts Bank over controversy surrounding the closure of Nigel Farage's account.

links.text: -Race, Michael (27 July 2023). "Farage account row leads Coutts Bank boss to quit". BBC News. Retrieved 27 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: 28 July   The High Court concludes that Sadiq Khan's plan to extend the Ultra Low Emission Zone (ULEZ) around London is lawful and can proceed.

links.text: -"Sadiq Khan wins high court battle over London Ulez extension – UK politics live". The Guardian. 28 July 2023. Retrieved 28 July 2023.-
-"Sadiq Khan's plan to extend £12.50 Ulez zone is lawful – court". BBC News. 28 July 2023. Retrieved 28 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: Media outlets, including BBC News, report that the Infrastructure and Projects Authority has given the HS2 project an "unachievable" rating in a report published on 20 July.

links.text: -Slow, Oliver (30 July 2023). "HS2: Rail link rated 'unachievable' by infrastructure watchdog". BBC News. Retrieved 30 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: Sunak orders a review of Low Traffic Neighbourhoods, declaring himself to be on the side of drivers.

links.text: -Slow, Oliver (30 July 2023). "Sunak orders review of low traffic neighbourhoods in pro-motorist message". BBC News. Retrieved 30 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: Sunak announces that over 100 new licenses will be granted for oil and gas drilling in the North Sea, a decision heavily criticised by environmental groups and opposition MPs as incompatible with the UK's climate change commitments. Sunak insists the plan is "entirely consistent" with reaching net zero, and says that a quarter of UK energy needs will come from oil and gas even after 2050.

links.text: -"Sunak insists new oil and gas 'entirely consistent' with net zero". BBC News. 31 July 2023. Retrieved 31 July 2023.-
-"New North Sea oil and gas licences will send 'wrecking ball' through climate commitments". The Guardian. 31 July 2023. Retrieved 31 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: New rules come into force from the Financial Conduct Authority requiring banks to prove they are offering their customers fair value, such as passing on interest rate rises to savers.

links.text: -Race, Michael; Peachey, Kevin; Edser, Nick (31 July 2023). "Savings: Banks with lowest rates will face action, watchdog warns". BBC News. Retrieved 31 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: The final date on which non-barcoded stamps can be used when posting mail.

links.text: -"Final day to use Royal Mail stamps without barcode before surcharge fee applies". Sky News. 31 July 2023. Retrieved 31 July 2023.-

Data.event_text: Nationwide reports that house prices fell by 3.8% in July, the sharpest decline since July 2009.

links.text: -"UK house prices fall at sharpest rate for 14 years, says Nationwide". BBC News. 1 August 2023. Retrieved 1 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: The UK's first permanent drone delivery service begins, with Royal Mail and Skyports establishing a daily inter-island mail distribution between three islands on Orkney.

links.text: -"UK's first drone mail service begins in Orkney". BBC News. 1 August 2023. Retrieved 1 August 2023.-
-"Royal Mail and Skyports Drone Services launch fully electric drone deliveries in Orkney". International Distributions Services. 1 August 2023. Retrieved 1 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: Changes on excise duty for alcohol come into force, with the tax levied depending on a drink's strength.

links.text: -Hooker, Lucy (1 August 2023). "Tax jumps on wine and spirits but falls on fizz". BBC News. Retrieved 1 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: Former SNP MP Margaret Ferrier loses her seat, following a successful recall petition, triggering a by-election.

links.text: -"Margaret Ferrier: By-election triggered as Covid breach MP unseated". BBC News. 1 August 2023. Retrieved 1 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: 2 August  COVID-19 in the UK The UK Health Security Agency reports the spread of a new variant known as EG.5.1.

links.text: -"SARS-CoV-2 genome sequence prevalence and growth rate update: 2 August 2023". UK Health Security Agency. 2 August 2023. Retrieved 3 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: The National Risk Register publishes its latest report on future threats facing the UK. It puts the chance of another pandemic at between 5% and 25%. Other risks include extreme weather caused by worsening climate change, advances in artificial intelligence (AI) systems, terrorism such as cyberattacks on infrastructure, and the assassination of public figures.

links.text: -"Future pandemic and extreme weather among key threats to UK". BBC News. 3 August 2023. Retrieved 3 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: Greenpeace activists climb onto the roof of Rishi Sunak's North Yorkshire home, unfurling sheets of black fabric, in protest at his recent decision to expand oil and gas production in the North Sea.

links.text: -"Greenpeace protesters drape giant oil-black fabric over Sunak's mansion". The Guardian. 3 August 2023. Retrieved 3 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: The Bank of England raises its baseline interest rate from 5% to 5.25%, the 14th consecutive increase and the highest level since April 2008. The Bank also predicts inflation to fall below 5% in the final quarter of 2023.

links.text: -"Bank of England raises interest rate to 5.25%". BBC News. 3 August 2023. Retrieved 3 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: Brexit Checks on fresh food from the EU are delayed for a fifth time, amid concerns over red tape.

links.text: -"UK Brexit checks on fresh food from EU delayed for fifth time, reports say". The Guardian. 3 August 2023. Retrieved 3 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: Homeware retailer Wilko files a notice of intention to call in administrators after failing to secure a buyer, putting 12,000 jobs at risk.

links.text: -"Wilko homeware chain on brink of collapse". BBC News. 3 August 2023. Retrieved 3 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: Butterfly Conservation reports a four-fold increase in red admiral sightings compared to the previous year, likely a result of higher temperatures in the UK.

links.text: -"Red Admiral butterflies: Climate change sees migratory species stay in UK, says charity". BBC News. 3 August 2023. Retrieved 3 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: Around 4,000 scouts from the UK attending the World Jamboree in South Korea are to be moved to hotels due to the ongoing 2023 Asia heat wave.

links.text: -Gregory, James; Seddon, Sean (4 August 2023). "UK Scouts pulled out of camp after S Korea heatwave". BBC News. Retrieved 4 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: A royal spokesman confirms there will be no official public events to mark the first anniversary of the death of Elizabeth II.

links.text: -Coughlan, Sean (4 August 2023). "Queen Elizabeth: No public event for anniversary of late monarch's death". BBC News. Retrieved 4 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: The mother and stepfather of Jacob Crouch, a 10-month-old baby who died at his Derbyshire home in 2020, are found guilty of causing him severe injuries leading to death. The mother, 33-year-old Gemma Barton, is acquitted of murder, but found guilty of causing or allowing the death of a child, as well as child cruelty, and is sentenced to 10 years in prison. Stepfather Craig Crouch is found guilty of murder and receives a minimum term of 28 years in prison.

links.text: -"Jacob Crouch's stepfather jailed for minimum 28 years for baby's murder". BBC News. 4 August 2023. Retrieved 4 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: Storm Antoni hits the UK, the first Met Office-named storm of the year, with forecasters warning of "unseasonably" strong winds that could pose a danger to life over the weekend. A top wind gust of 78 mph is recorded at Berry Head in Devon, which is considered a potential record for the time of year.

links.text: -"Storm Antoni: Danger to life warning as strong winds and heavy rain hits UK". BBC News. 5 August 2023. Retrieved 5 August 2023.-
-PA Media (5 August 2023). "Storm Antoni hits UK with near-80mph gusts and train disruption in south-west". The Guardian. Retrieved 5 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: The biggest NHS privatisation since the Blair years is announced, with eight new community diagnostic centres (CDCs) being planned in a bid to cut record-high waiting lists. A further five NHS-run CDCs are also announced.

links.text: -"New diagnostic centres open in 'biggest private expansion since Blair' – as NHS waiting lists at all-time high". Yahoo News. 4 August 2023. Retrieved 5 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: 5 August  The 18th century Crooked House, once known as "Britain's wonkiest pub", is gutted by a fire. The pub is demolished two days later. Police subsequently confirm they are treating the fire as arson.

links.text: -"The Crooked House: Fire rips through famed 'wonky' pub". BBC News. 6 August 2023. Retrieved 6 August 2023.-
-Gall, Caroline (9 August 2023). "Crooked House: Fire at 'wonkiest' pub treated as arson". BBC News. Retrieved 9 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: Secretary of State for Justice Alex Chalk confirms that the rule deducting living costs from compensation paid to people who have been wrongfully convicted will be scrapped.

links.text: -Seddon, Sean (6 August 2023). "Prison living costs rule scrapped for wrongly convicted". BBC News. Retrieved 6 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: Greetings card retailer Clintons are to close around 20% of their outlets to cut back on expenditure.

links.text: -Jordan, Dearbail (6 August 2023). "Clintons set to close around a fifth of its shops". BBC News. Retrieved 6 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: 7 August  The first group of asylum seekers to be housed on the Bibby Stockholm while they wait for the cases to be processed arrive on the barge following delays over safety concerns.

links.text: -"Bibby Stockholm: First asylum seekers board housing barge in Dorset". BBC News. 7 August 2023. Retrieved 7 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: The Police Service of Northern Ireland issues an apology after a data breach led to the details of its officers being published online.

links.text: -O'Neill, Julian (8 August 2023). "PSNI: Major data breach identifies thousands of officers and civilian staff". BBC News. Retrieved 8 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: The Electoral Commission warns people to look out for unauthorised use of their data after revealing it was the victim of a "complex cyber-attack" in , which was not discovered until October 2022.

links.text: -Seddon, Paul (8 August 2023). "Cyber-attack on UK's electoral registers revealed". BBC News. Retrieved 8 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: The Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation recommends the Autumn 2023 programme of COVID-19 booster vaccines should be routinely offered to all over-65s, as well as those under 65 in clinical risk groups, care home residents and frontline health workers. This marks a change from 2022 when all adults over 50 were offered the booster. The flu vaccine will also be offered to over 65s after the age was dropped to 50 during the pandemic.

links.text: -"Winter Covid vaccines axed for under-65s". BBC News. 8 August 2023. Retrieved 8 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: 9 August  A second Police Service of Northern Ireland data breach is revealed after it emerges a spreadsheet containing the names of 200 officers was stolen from a car in July 2023.

links.text: -O'Neill, Julian; Fox, Matt; Gordon, Ali (9 August 2023). "PSNI data: Police investigate second breach after documents stolen". BBC News. Retrieved 9 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: High street bargain homeware retailer Wilko goes into administration. The move puts 12,000 jobs across 400 shops at risk.

links.text: -"Wilko collapses into administration putting 12,000 jobs at risk". BBC News. 10 August 2023. Retrieved 10 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: Simon Byrne, the Chief Constable of the Police Service of Northern Ireland, says he is "deeply sorry" about two "industrial scale" data breaches, but will not resign over the controversy.

links.text: -Purdy, Finn (10 August 2023). "PSNI chief admits officers anxious and angry at data breach". BBC News. Retrieved 10 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: Coronation of Charles III and Camilla The Royal Mint unveils a special official Coronation 50 pence coin.

links.text: -"Special King Charles Coronation 50p coins issued". BBC News BBC. 10 August 2023. Retrieved 10 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: Data from the Office for National Statistics shows the UK economy grew by an average 0.2% between April and June 2023. This includes a better than expected increase of 0.5% for June as a result of warm weather which boosted both the construction and hospitality industries.

links.text: -Race, Michael (11 August 2023). "Warm weather in June boosts UK economy". BBC News. Retrieved 11 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: Migrants are temporarily moved from the Bibby Stockholm after traces of the Legionella bacteria are found in the water supply.

links.text: -"Migrants being moved off barge over bacteria fears". BBC News. 11 August 2023. Retrieved 11 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: The number of migrants who have crossed the English Channel since 2018 passes 100,000.

links.text: -Maisner, Stuart (11 August 2023). "Channel migrants: More than 100,000 crossings made since 2018". BBC News. Retrieved 11 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: England captain Harry Kane joins German champions Bayern Munich on a four-year deal, ending his record-breaking career at Tottenham Hotspur.

links.text: -"Harry Kane joins Bayern Munich ending record-breaking Tottenham career". BBC News. 12 August 2023. Retrieved 12 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: Six people are killed and 58 rescued by British and French coastguards after a boat carrying migrants sinks off the French coast, near Sangatte, in the English Channel.

links.text: -Fisher, Megan; Kleiderman, Alex; Jones, Simon (12 August 2023). "Migrant boat sinks in Channel killing six people". BBC News. Retrieved 12 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: 14 August  Health Secretary Steve Barclay confirms "no-one has been harmed" following the discovery of legionella bacteria on the Bibby Stockholm.

links.text: -Mackintosh, Thomas; Slow, Oliver (14 August 2023). "Bibby Stockholm: No-one harmed over discovery of Legionella on barge – health secretary". BBC News. Retrieved 14 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: BBC News reports that five suspected spies for Russia were arrested in February 2023, three of whom have been charged in connection with the allegations.

links.text: -De Simone, Daniel; Britton, Jeremy (15 August 2023). "Suspected spies for Russia held in major UK security investigation". BBC News. Retrieved 15 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: Data published by the Office for National Statistics indicates that average UK wages increased by 7.8% between April and June 2023, their highest increase since comparable figures began in 2001.

links.text: -Jordan, Dearbail (15 August 2023). "Wage surge raises prospect of further interest rate hike". BBC News. Retrieved 15 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: Data released by the Office for National Statistics indicates that UK rents rose by an average of 5.3% in the year to July 2023, the highest rise since comparable records began in 2016.

links.text: -Peachey, Kevin (16 August 2023). "UK rents rise to highest rates since 2016 –". BBC News. Retrieved 16 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: UK inflation fell from 7.9% in June to 6.8% in July with the fall in energy costs helping to bring it down, but food and hospitality prices remained high and continued to have an impact.

links.text: -Race, Michael (16 August 2023). "Inflation slows to 6.8% but flights and hotels keep prices high –". BBC News. Retrieved 16 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: 17 August  A Level results are published in England, Wales and Northern Ireland, with grades returning to pre-pandemic levels; 27.2% of all grades marked are rated as A* or A.

links.text: -Shearing, Hazel (17 August 2023). "Top A-levels fall, with steepest drop in England". BBC News. Retrieved 17 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: Former nurse Lucy Letby, 33, is found guilty of murdering seven babies, and attempting to murder six others, at the Countess of Chester Hospital between June 2015 and June 2016, following a trial which began 10 months ago. She becomes the most prolific killer of babies in the UK in modern times. She is cleared on two charges of attempted murder, while the jury fails to reach verdicts on two further charges of attempted murder. The UK government orders an independent inquiry into the case.

links.text: -"Nurse Lucy Letby guilty of murdering seven babies on neonatal unit". BBC News. 18 August 2023. Retrieved 18 August 2023.-
-"Government orders independent inquiry following Lucy Letby verdict". GOV.UK. 18 August 2023. Retrieved 18 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: COVID-19 vaccination in the UK The UK Health Security Agency supports a proposal for the commercial sale of COVID-19 vaccines to the public, for those wishing to top up their immunity, after the age limit on the NHS booster programme is raised from 50 to 65.

links.text: -"Covid booster jabs to be approved for sale to UK public". The Guardian. 18 August 2023. Retrieved 18 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: HM Treasury announces that banks will be fined if they fail to provide people with adequate cash withdrawal and deposit facilities. The policy will require cash withdrawal and deposit facilities to be available within a mile of residents and businesses in an urban setting, and three miles in rural settings.

links.text: -Peachey, Kevin (18 August 2023). "Banks face fines if they breach rules on access to cash". BBC News. Retrieved 18 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: 20 August  2023 FIFA Women's World Cup Spain win 10 against England in the final of the tournament.

links.text: -"Women's World Cup final: England lose to Spain in Sydney". BBC Sport. 20 August 2023. Retrieved 20 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: 21 August  Following her conviction on 18 August, Lucy Letby is sentenced at Manchester Crown Court to a whole life order for the 14 charges she was convicted of. Justice James Goss states that her "cruel, calculated and cynical campaign of child murder" means she should never be released from prison.

links.text: -"Serial killer nurse Lucy Letby given whole-life sentence". BBC News. 21 August 2023. Retrieved 21 August 2023.-
-Halliday, Josh (21 August 2023). "Lucy Letby sentenced to whole-life jail term after murdering seven babies". The Guardian. Retrieved 21 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: Official figures show that Government borrowing in July was £4.3bn, lower than the £5bn forecast by economists.

links.text: -"Public borrowing below forecasts despite July rise". BBC News. 22 August 2023. Retrieved 22 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: Former Metropolitan Police officer Adam Provan is jailed for 16 years for multiple rapes against a teenage girl and a female police officer.

links.text: -"Adam Provan: Former Metropolitan Police officer jailed for 16 years for raping woman and girl". Sky News. 22 August 2023. Retrieved 22 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: It is reported that art dealer Ittai Gradel alerted the British Museum about possible missing items in 2021 but was told "all objects were accounted for".

links.text: -Razzall, Katie; Saunders, Emma (22 August 2023). "British Museum bosses first alerted to thefts in 2021". BBC News. Retrieved 22 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: 23 August  It is reported that doctors at Oxford's Churchill Hospital have carried out the UK's first womb transplant, with a 34-year-old woman receiving her sister's womb in a 17-hour operation that took place in February 2023.

links.text: -Walsh, Fergus (23 August 2023). "Woman receives sister's womb in first UK transplant". BBC News. Retrieved 23 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: Data released by the Home Office shows that 175,000 people were waiting to have their claims for asylum assessed at the end of June 2023, an increase of 44% on the same time in 2022.

links.text: -Gregory, James; Easton, Mark (24 August 2023). "Asylum backlog rises to record high, official figures show". BBC News. Retrieved 24 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: GCSE results are published in England, Wales and Northern Ireland, with 68.2% of all entries marked at grades 4/C and above. It is the second fall in overall results, taking them almost back to pre-pandemic levels.

links.text: -Shearing, Hazel (24 August 2023). "GCSE passes fall, with steepest drop in England". BBC News. Retrieved 24 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: Ofgem confirms the energy price cap will fall again in October, with an annual gas and electricity bill at around £1,923.

links.text: -Peachey, Kevin (25 August 2023). "Energy bills drop slightly for winter but will remain high". BBC News. Retrieved 25 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: The National Crime Agency launches a criminal investigation after linking 88 UK deaths with an online seller from Canada accused of selling them a poisonous substance so they could commit suicide.

links.text: -Crawford, Angus (25 August 2023). "88 UK deaths linked to Canada 'poison seller'". BBC News. Retrieved 25 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: 26 August  Conservative MP Nadine Dorries resigns her Parliamentary seat two months after originally saying she would do so, accusing Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of abandoning "the fundamental principles of Conservatism" and that "history will not judge [him] kindly".

links.text: -"Nadine Dorries: Conservative MP attacks PM as she quits Commons". BBC News. 26 August 2023. Retrieved 26 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: 28 August  Hundreds of flights to and from the UK are delayed following technical problems with the UK's air traffic control system.

links.text: -Slow, Oliver; Rhoden-Paul, Andre (28 August 2023). "Airlines warn of UK flight delays over air traffic control fault". BBC News. Retrieved 28 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: Martin Rolfe, chief executive of the National Air Transport Service confirms that an initial investigation into the disruption caused to the UK's air traffic control system indicates it to be as a result of flight data received. As passengers continue to face delays in catching flights, the incident is to be investigated by the Civil Aviation Authority.

links.text: -Mackintosh, Thomas; Harrison, Emma (29 August 2023). "Cancelled flights: Air traffic disruption caused by flight data issue". BBC News. Retrieved 29 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak announces plans to introduce legislation that will compel convicted criminals to attend their sentencing hearings, by force if necessary, or face more time in prison.

links.text: -Walsh, Aoife (30 August 2023). "Criminals to be forced to attend sentencing hearings after Lucy Letby calls". BBC News. Retrieved 30 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: Health Secretary Steve Barclay announces that the inquiry into the circumstances surrounding Lucy Letby's crimes has been upgraded to a statutory hearing, meaning that witnesses can be compelled to give evidence.

links.text: -"Lucy Letby: Inquiry given powers to compel witnesses to give evidence". BBC News. 30 August 2023. Retrieved 30 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: Property website Zoopla forecasts that UK house sales for 2023 are on course to be at their lowest since 2012, with an estimated one million completed by the end of the year, a fifth lower than 2022.

links.text: -Sri-Pathma, Vishala (30 August 2023). "House sales to slump to lowest in over a decade". BBC News. Retrieved 30 August 2023.-

Data.event_text: A crisis emerges in schools, hospitals, and other public buildings, centred around the use of reinforced autoclaved aerated concrete (RAAC), a widely used but outdated material believed to be unsafe and in danger of crumbling. The announcements come just days before the beginning of the new academic year.

links.text: -"England's concrete crisis could extend to hospitals and courts, experts say". The Guardian. 2 September 2023. Retrieved 2 September 2023.-
-"Eye-watering sums being spent to make crumbly concrete safe – MP". BBC News. 2 September 2023. Retrieved 2 September 2023.-
-"How Long Have We Known About RAAC Issues?". BBC. 1 September 2023. Retrieved 1 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: Figures published by the Nationwide Building Society indicate UK house prices in August 2023 were 5.3% lower than those in August 2022, the largest fall since 2009.

links.text: -Race, Michael (1 September 2023). "House prices see biggest yearly decline since 2009". BBC News. Retrieved 1 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: Octopus Energy announces plans to buy Shell Energy, giving Octopus an additional 1.4 million customers.

links.text: -"Octopus to buy Shell's household energy firm". BBC News. 1 September 2023. Retrieved 1 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: Chancellor Jeremy Hunt says the UK government will "spend what it takes" to put right the problem of defective concrete in schools, and says that structural problems could be identified in more schools and other public buildings.

links.text: -Baker, Graeme (3 September 2023). "Jeremy Hunt says government will 'spend what it takes' to make schools safe". BBC News. Retrieved 3 September 2023.-
-Rogers, Alexandra (3 September 2023). "More schools and other public buildings with structural problems could come to light, Jeremy Hunt says". Sky News. Retrieved 3 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: Tesco chief executive Ken Murphy announces that staff at the retailer will be offered body cameras following a rise in violent incidents.

links.text: -"Tesco staff offered body cameras over crime fears". BBC News. 3 September 2023. Retrieved 3 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: UK government data indicates 872 migrants crossed the English Channel the previous day, the highest daily number of 2023.

links.text: -Blunt, Rosie (3 September 2023). "Highest number of migrants cross Channel in 2023". BBC News. Retrieved 3 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: Labour leader Keir Starmer performs a cabinet reshuffle, as MPs return to Westminster after the summer break. This includes Angela Rayner becoming both Shadow Levelling Up Secretary and Shadow Deputy Prime Minister.

links.text: -"Rayner gets new role as Starmer reshuffles Labour team". BBC News. 4 September 2023. Retrieved 4 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: Simon Byrne resigns as Chief Constable of the Police Service of Northern Ireland with immediate effect following a number of recent controversies.

links.text: -"Police Service of Northern Ireland Chief Constable Simon Byrne resigns". BBC News. 4 September 2023. Retrieved 4 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: The Met Office issues a heat health alert for much of the country, with temperatures forecast to reach as high as 32 °C later in the week.

links.text: -"UK weather: yellow heat warning across most of England as temperatures to hit 32C". The Guardian. 4 September 2023. Retrieved 4 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: BBC News reports that a record number of Asian hornets sightings could have devastating consequences for the UK's bee population for many years to come.

links.text: -Briggs, Helen (4 September 2023). "UK bees in danger as Asian hornet sightings rise". BBC News. Retrieved 5 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: Birmingham City Council, the largest local authority in Europe, declares itself effectively bankrupt. The crisis, which prevents all but essential spending to protect core services, is linked to a £760m bill to settle equal pay claims, along with implementation of a new IT system.

links.text: -"Birmingham City Council 'effectively bankrupt'". BBC News. 5 September 2023. Retrieved 5 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: As parts of the UK experience a heat wave, the UK Health Security Agency upgrades a yellow heat health alert to an amber warning in eight of the UK's nine regions amid forecasts that temperatures will reach 32 °C.

links.text: -Slow, Oliver; Hancock, Sam (4 September 2023). "UK heatwave: Heat-health alert upgraded to amber as temperatures to hit 32C". BBC News. Retrieved 5 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: The UK government announces that nitrous oxide will be reclassified as a Class C drug and made illegal by the end of the year, with possession carrying a sentence of up to two years in prison.

links.text: -Gillett, Francesca (5 September 2023). "Nitrous oxide: Laughing gas to be illegal by end of year". BBC. Retrieved 5 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: Home Secretary Suella Braverman announces that Russia's mercenary Wagner Group is to be proscribed as a terrorist organisation.

links.text: -"Wagner to be declared a terrorist organisation by UK". BBC News. 5 September 2023. Retrieved 5 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: 6 September  A manhunt is launched for remand prisoner Daniel Abed Khalife following his escape from HMP Wandsworth.

links.text: -Seddon, Sean; Sandford, Daniel (6 September 2023). "Hunt for terror suspect ex-soldier Daniel Khalife after Wandsworth prison escape". BBC News. Retrieved 6 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: The UK rejoins the EU's Horizon scientific research programme.

links.text: -"UK rejoins EU science research scheme Horizon". BBC News. 7 September 2023. Retrieved 7 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: Justice Secretary Alex Chalk announces an independent inquiry into the escape of Daniel Khalife from Wandsworth Prison. The inquiry will have two areas of focus  a review of the "placement and categorisation" of all inmates at Wandsworth, and an investigation of all people in custody currently charged with terror offences.

links.text: -Brown, Faye (7 September 2023). "Daniel Abel Khalife: Independent inquiry to take place into terror suspect's escape". Sky News. Retrieved 7 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: The UK's first EV-only manufacturing plant begins production at Ellesmere Port, Cheshire.

links.text: -"Historic day as Vauxhall's Ellesmere Port plant starts electric van production". CheshireLive. 7 September 2023. Retrieved 7 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: The UK experiences a fourth day of temperatures exceeding 30 °C (86 °F), the highest consecutive number on record for the month of September, with hot weather expected to continue until the weekend.

links.text: -"September heatwave sets new record". BBC News. 7 September 2023. Retrieved 7 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: 8 September  The first anniversary of the death of Elizabeth II is marked by gun salutes at Hyde Park and the Tower of London, as well as the release of a short message from Charles III along with a previously unreleased portrait of the Queen taken in 1968.

links.text: -Gregory, James (8 September 2023). "King Charles III message marks anniversary of Queen Elizabeth II's death". BBC News. Retrieved 8 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: 9 September  Following a four-day manhunt, Daniel Khalife is arrested by the Metropolitan Police in Chiswick, London.
The Sunday Times reports that two men have been arrested under the Official Secrets Act, including a researcher in the UK Parliament accused of spying for China.

links.text: -"China spy claims as Parliament researcher arrested". BBC News. 10 September 2023. Retrieved 10 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: Mo Farah, considered one of the greatest British athletes of all time, takes part in the final race of his career at age 40, finishing fourth in the Great North Run.

links.text: -"Great North Run 2023: Mo Farah fourth in final race of career". BBC News. 10 September 2023. Retrieved 10 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: The Metropolitan Police confirm that Daniel Khalife has been charged with escaping from Wandsworth Prison. He appears before Westminster Magistrates Court the following day, where he is remanded in custody until 29 September.

links.text: -Jones, Harrison (10 September 2023). "Daniel Khalife charged over Wandsworth prison escape". BBC News. Retrieved 10 September 2023.-
-Sandford, Daniel (11 September 2023). "Daniel Khalife: Terror suspect may have used bedsheet to escape, court hears". BBC News. Retrieved 11 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: The GMB Union confirms that the UK's 400 Wilko stores will close by early October after a bid to rescue the retailer fell through.

links.text: -Jones, Lora; Simpson, Emma (11 September 2023). "Wilko: All 400 stores to close by early October". BBC News. Retrieved 11 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: Home Secretary Suella Braverman says she is seeking "urgent advice" on potentially banning the American Bully XL dog breed following an attack by a dog on an 11-year-old girl in Birmingham.

links.text: -"American bully XL dogs: Suella Braverman orders 'urgent advice' on banning breed". BBC News. 11 September 2023. Retrieved 11 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: Pepco Group, owners of Poundland, announce they will take on the lease of 71 Wilko stores and convert them into Poundland outlets.

links.text: -"Poundland owner to take on up to 71 Wilko stores". BBC News. 12 September 2023. Retrieved 14 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: Government data reveals that average wages increased by 7.8% from May to July, matching the pace of inflation for the first time since 2021.

links.text: -"Pay matches price rises even as unemployment climbs". BBC News. 12 September 2023. Retrieved 13 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: A joint study carried out by the University of Exeter, the University of Surrey and the Working Party on Sexual Misconduct in Surgery highlights the experiences of female surgeons, many of whom say they have faced sexual harassment, sexual assault or been raped by male colleagues.

links.text: -"Female surgeons sexually assaulted while operating". BBC News. 11 September 2023. Retrieved 13 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: Stonegate Group, the UK's largest pub chain, announces plans to introduce dynamic pricing during evenings and weekends at around 800 of its 4,000 outlets.

links.text: -"Slug & Lettuce owner to charge more at peak hours". BBC News. 12 September 2023. Retrieved 13 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: Data from the Office for National Statistics indicates the UK economy shrank by 0.5% during July, which is largely attributed to strike action and wet weather.

links.text: -"UK economy shrinks more than expected as rain and strikes hit". BBC News. 13 September 2023. Retrieved 13 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: Data published by UK Finance shows payments by cash in the UK rose during 2022 for the first time in ten years, but were still lower than those by debit and credit card.

links.text: -Peachey, Kevin (13 September 2023). "Cash payments rise for first time in 10 years". BBC News. Retrieved 18 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: Following a recent spate of dog attacks, primarily involving the American XL bully, the government announces that the breed will be banned under the Dangerous Dogs Act by the end of the year.

links.text: -"American bully XL dogs to be banned by end of year – Sunak". BBC News. 15 September 2023. Retrieved 15 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: Port Talbot Steelworks is allocated up to £500m by the UK government in a bid to keep the plant open and produce steel using greener methods.

links.text: -"Tata Steel: Port Talbot steelworks given £500m by UK government". BBC News. 15 September 2023. Retrieved 15 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: Marks & Spencer becomes the latest high street retailer to announce it is scrapping plastic bags in favour of paper ones.

links.text: -"Marks & Spencer scraps plastic for paper bags". BBC News. 15 September 2023. Retrieved 15 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: Comedian and actor Russell Brand is accused by four women of rape, sexual assaults, and emotional abuse between 2006 and 2013, following a joint investigation by the Sunday Times and Channel 4's Dispatches. Brand releases a video denying "serious criminal allegations".

links.text: -"Russell Brand accused of sexual assault by four women". BBC News. 16 September 2023. Retrieved 16 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: Christine Middlemiss, the UK's Chief Veterinary Officer, says there will not be a cull of American bully XL dogs following Sunak's announcement that the breed is to be banned.

links.text: -Harrison, Emma (16 September 2023). "American bully XLs will not be culled under ban, says chief vet". BBC News. Retrieved 16 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: Solicitors representing convicted killer nurse Lucy Letby announce that she will be applying for permission to appeal against her convictions.[citation needed]
COVID-19 vaccination in the UK New booster vaccines begin rolling out for people aged 65 and over in England, as a precaution against a highly mutated new COVID-19 variant called Pirola.

links.text: -"Covid boosters: Over-65s called for jabs as hospital cases rise". BBC News. 18 September 2023. Retrieved 18 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: A new palm oil substitute called PALM-ALT is presented by researchers at Queen Margaret University in Scotland. The plant-based ingredient is shown to be 70% better for the environment than conventional palm oil and is described as "the holy grail to replace it."

links.text: -"'This could be the holy grail to replace palm oil' – research team". BBC News. 18 September 2023. Retrieved 18 September 2023.-
-"University develops a replacement for palm oil that is healthy and environmentally friendly". Queen Margaret University. 18 September 2023. Retrieved 18 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: Conservative MP Dehenna Davison resigns as a levelling up minister, saying "chronic migraines" have made it "impossible" to do her job.

links.text: -"Chronic migraines have forced me to quit, says Dehenna Davison". BBC News. 18 September 2023. Retrieved 18 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: Russell Brand's live tour is postponed, as police investigate a further allegation of sexual assault by the celebrity, dating back to 2003.

links.text: -"Russell Brand shows postponed as police look into 2003 claim". BBC News. 18 September 2023. Retrieved 18 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: The UK government announces that Post Office workers who had wrongful convictions for false accounting and theft overturned will each be offered £600,000 in compensation.

links.text: -Nanji, Noor; Simpson, Emma (18 September 2023). "Post Office: Horizon scandal victims offered £600,000 compensation". BBC News. Retrieved 18 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: The UK government announces that commissioners will be appointed to oversee the running of Birmingham City Council following its recent financial troubles.

links.text: -Pearce, Vanessa; Mayor, Rob (19 September 2023). "Government sending in officials to run Birmingham". BBC News. Retrieved 19 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: The Scottish Government begins its legal challenge against Westminster over the UK government's decision to block the controversial Gender Recognition Reform (Scotland) Bill.

links.text: -"Court challenge over Scotland's gender bill set for September". BBC News. 27 June 2023. Retrieved 27 June 2023.-

Data.event_text: Data released by the Office for National Statistics show that inflation fell from 6.8% in July to 6.7% in August, something that is attributed to a fall in food prices.

links.text: -Nanji, Noor; Islam, Faisal (20 September 2023). "UK inflation: Slowing food prices drive surprise fall". BBC News. Retrieved 20 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: Sunak announces a major rethink of the UK government's strategy to achieve net zero carbon output in the UK by 2050, including a delay in banning the sale of new petrol and diesel cars from 2030 to 2035.

links.text: -Francis, Sam (20 September 2023). "Rishi Sunak delays petrol car ban in major shift on green policies". BBC News. Retrieved 20 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: The Bank of England holds interest rates at 5.25% after inflation for August was lower than expected.

links.text: -Thomas, Daniel; Islam, Faisal (21 September 2023). "UK interest rate freeze ends run of 14 straight increases". BBC News. Retrieved 21 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: Five Bulgarian nationals suspected of spying for Russia are to be charged with conspiracy to conduct espionage.

links.text: -De Simone, Daniel (21 September 2023). "Five to be charged in UK with spying for Russia". BBC News. Retrieved 21 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: Charles III addresses the French Senate during his state visit to France.

links.text: -Coughlan, Sean (21 September 2023). "King's diplomatic speech to French Senate receives standing ovation". BBC News. Retrieved 21 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: News Corp chairman Rupert Murdoch announces his retirement and plan to hand over his businesses to his son Lachlan. Murdoch additionally owned the American broadcaster Fox and formerly Sky Group.

links.text: -"Who is Rupert Murdoch?". BBC News. 8 July 2011. Retrieved 21 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: It is reported that eight-year-old Aditi Shankar has become the first child in the UK to receive a kidney transplant that will not require her to take medication to prevent the organ being rejected, and that she is healthy and has returned to school.

links.text: -Roberts, Michelle (22 September 2023). "Girl receives UK's first rejection-free kidney from mum". BBC News. Retrieved 22 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: In his first statement since further allegations were made against him, Russell Brand posts a video on social media describing his week as "extraordinary and distressing".

links.text: -"Russell Brand makes first comments since sexual assault allegations". BBC News. 22 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: The government's home energy efficiency taskforce is scrapped.

links.text: -"Rishi Sunak scraps home energy efficiency taskforce". BBC News. 23 September 2023. Retrieved 23 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: Members of the anti-monarchist pressure group Republic stage what they describe as the "first-ever" protest inside Buckingham Palace.

links.text: -Foster, Max; Pokharel, Sugam (23 September 2023). "Anti-monarchy campaigners stage protest inside Buckingham Palace". CNN. Retrieved 24 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: 24 September  Home Secretary Suella Braverman orders a review into armed policing, after 300 firearms officers hand in their weapons, following concerns over a police officer charged with murdering 24-year-old Chris Kaba. Most of the officers return to their duties the following day.

links.text: -"Chris Kaba: Home secretary orders review into armed policing". BBC News. 24 September 2023. Retrieved 24 September 2023.-
-"Chris Kaba: Army stood down as enough Met Police armed officers return to duty". BBC News. 25 September 2023. Retrieved 25 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: A hearing at Manchester Crown Court determines that Lucy Letby will face a retrial for one of the six counts of attempted murder that the jury at her original trial was unable to reach a verdict on; a provisional trial date is set for 10 June 2024.

links.text: -"Child serial killer Lucy Letby to face retrial over attempted murder charge". BBC News. 25 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: The Metropolitan Police are to investigate allegations of non-recent sexual offences following recent reports about comedian Russell Brand.

links.text: -"Russell Brand: Police receive further allegations against comedian". BBC News. 25 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: Home Secretary Suella Braverman tells a US think tank the 1951 Refugees Convention is no longer fit for the modern age, and that being discriminated against for being gay or female should not be enough to qualify for refugee status. The United Nations High Commission for Refugees rejects the comments.

links.text: -Morton, Becky (26 September 2023). "UN refugee agency rejects Suella Braverman asylum comments". BBC News. Retrieved 26 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: Dr Mike McKean, vice-president for policy at the Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health, says that public health messaging suggesting vaping is 95% safer than smoking is ineffective as a growing number of children are using e-cigarettes and experiencing health problems, and that messaging should have made it clearer that vaping should be for adults trying to give up smoking.

links.text: -Pym, Hugh; Watkinson, Lucy (26 September 2023). "Vapes '95% safer' than cigarettes messaging backfired". BBC News. Retrieved 26 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: Five Bulgarian nationals accused of being part of a Russian spy ring appear in court in central London and are remanded in custody.

links.text: -De Simone, Daniel (26 September 2023). "Five alleged Russian spies appear in London court". BBC News. Retrieved 26 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: The Rosebank oil and gas field off Shetland, the UK's largest untapped oil field, is granted consent by regulators, amid widespread concerns over its contribution to climate change.

links.text: -"Rosebank oil field given go-ahead by regulator". BBC News. 27 September 2023. Retrieved 27 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: GB News suspends Laurence Fox as a presenter while it investigates comments he made on the channel about Ava Evans, a female journalist. Later in the day, Dan Wootton is suspended over the same incident.

links.text: -"GB News suspends Laurence Fox over comments about journalist Ava Evans". BBC News. 27 September 2023. Retrieved 27 September 2023.-
-"GB News suspends Wootton after Fox comments". BBC News. 27 September 2023. Retrieved 27 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: The UK's first drugs consumption room gets the go-ahead in Glasgow, allowing heroin and cocaine addicts to use the substances under supervision.

links.text: -"UK's first consumption room for illegal drugs given go-ahead". BBC News. 27 September 2023. Retrieved 27 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: A report by the Education Select Committee draws attention to the increased number of absences from schools in England, which has doubled since the COVID-19 pandemic; data for 202223 shows an average of 22.3% of school pupils were absent, compared to between 10% and 12% in the years prior to the pandemic. A combination of mental health issues and the cost of living crisis are attributed to the increase.

links.text: -"School absences: The school picking kids up from home to boost attendance". BBC News. 26 September 2023. Retrieved 27 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: The 15-year-old girl killed in Croydon, South London the previous day is named locally as Elianne Andam. Police are given an extra 24 hours to question the 17-year-old suspect.

links.text: -"Croydon stabbing: Our hearts are broken, Elianne Andam's family says". BBC News. 28 September 2023. Retrieved 28 September 2023.-
-"Croydon: Boy, 17, held over killing of girl with 'bright future'". BBC News. 28 September 2023. Retrieved 28 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: The landmark Sycamore Gap Tree, beside Hadrian's Wall in Northumberland, is illegally felled. A 16-year-old boy is subsequently arrested on suspicion of criminal damage.

links.text: -"Sycamore Gap: Boy, 16, arrested after Hadrian's Wall tree felled". BBC News. 28 September 2023. Retrieved 28 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: A school bus carrying 58 people overturns between junction 4 and 5 of the M53 motorway, killing a 15-year-old girl and the driver. A major incident is declared by North West Ambulance Service and Liverpool's Alder Hey Children's Hospital. Dozens of others are treated for injuries, and several are hospitalised.

links.text: -"M53 crash: Teenage victim named as Jessica Baker". BBC News. 29 September 2023. Retrieved 30 September 2023.-
-"Girl, 14, and driver killed in M53 school bus crash". BBC News. 29 September 2023. Retrieved 29 September 2023.-
-"Girl, 14, and driver dead after school bus crash in Cheshire". The Guardian. 29 September 2023. Retrieved 29 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: A 17-year-old boy appears in court charged with the murder of Elianne Andam, and is remanded in youth detention to appear before the Old Bailey on 3 October.

links.text: -"Elianne Andam: Boy, 17, appears in court over murder of schoolgirl in Croydon". BBC News. 29 September 2023. Retrieved 29 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: A second person  a man in his 60s  is arrested in correction with the cutting-down of the world-famous Sycamore Gap Tree. The 16-year-old boy arrested over the incident the previous day is released on bail.

links.text: -"Sycamore Gap: Man in his 60s held after Hadrian's Wall tree cut down". BBC News. 29 September 2023. Retrieved 30 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: In an interview with The Sun, Prime Minister Rishi Sunak reinforces his pro-motorist stance, saying he wants to stop "hare-brained" road calming and safety schemes  including 20 mph zones and low-traffic neighbourhoods  putting an end to what he refers to as a "war on motorists".

links.text: -"Sunak vows to end 'hare-brain' road schemes". BBC News. 29 September 2023. Retrieved 30 September 2023.-

Data.event_text: Russell Brand faces a second police investigation, as Thames Valley Police announce they are looking into claims of harassment and stalking by the comedian.

links.text: -"Russell Brand: Thames Valley Police investigates allegations". BBC News. 2 October 2023. Retrieved 2 October 2023.-

Data.event_text: The price of a first class stamp rises from £1.10 to £1.25, the third increase in 18 months.

links.text: -"First class stamp price jumps to £1.25". BBC News. 2 October 2023. Retrieved 2 October 2023.-

Data.event_text: Chancellor Jeremy Hunt confirms the National Minimum Wage will rise to £11 an hour from April 2024.

links.text: -Morton, Becky (1 October 2023). "National living wage to rise to £11 an hour, Jeremy Hunt confirms". BBC News. Retrieved 2 October 2023.-

Data.event_text: The Met Office confirms that September 2023 was the joint warmest September on record for the UK, tying with 2006 with an average temperature of 15.2 °C.

links.text: -King, Simon (2 October 2023). "UK sees joint warmest September on record". BBC News. Retrieved 3 October 2023.-

Data.event_text: 3 October  Home Secretary Suella Braverman addresses the Conservative Party Conference and says a "hurricane" of migrants is coming to the UK.

links.text: -Seddon, Paul (3 October 2023). "Migration hurricane is coming, Suella Braverman tells Tories". BBC News. Retrieved 3 October 2023.-

Data.event_text: Rishi Sunak confirms that the West Midlands to Manchester portion of the High Speed 2 (HS2) rail link will be axed, which will free up £36bn to be spent on new transport projects in the North and Midlands. He also confirms that the southern portion of the line will run all the way from Birmingham to Euston, not just Old Oak Common as earlier reports had speculated.

links.text: -"Sunak pledges billions for northern transport as he axes HS2 line". BBC News. 4 October 2023. Retrieved 4 October 2023.-
-"Rishi Sunak scraps HS2 leg to Manchester and confirms plan to gradually raise smoking age – UK politics live". The Guardian. 4 October 2023. Retrieved 4 October 2023.-

Data.event_text: Sunak proposes that the age at which people can buy cigarettes and tobacco should rise by one year every year, so that eventually no-one can buy them, emulating a similar scheme announced recently in New Zealand.

links.text: -"Smoking age should rise from 18, by one year every year – Rishi Sunak". BBC News. 4 October 2023. Retrieved 4 October 2023.-

Data.event_text: Sunak confirms plans to replace A Levels and T Levels in England with a new qualification called the Advanced British Standard.

links.text: -Bryson, Julia; Jeffreys, Branwen (4 October 2023). "Advanced British Standard: Sunak qualification will replace A-levels and T-levels". BBC News. Retrieved 4 October 2023.-

Data.event_text: Laurence Fox is arrested "on suspicion of conspiring to commit criminal damage to ULEZ cameras and encouraging or assisting offences to be committed." He is subsequently fired from GB News, along with fellow presenter Calvin Robinson.

links.text: -"Laurence Fox arrested over comments urging people to vandalise Ulez cameras". The Guardian. 4 October 2023. Retrieved 4 October 2023.-
-"Laurence Fox and Calvin Robinson sacked by GB News". BBC News. 4 October 2023. Retrieved 4 October 2023.-

Data.event_text: Cheshire Police confirm they have launched an investigation into possible corporate manslaughter at the Countess of Chester Hospital, where killer nurse Lucy Letby was employed.

links.text: -Hirst, Lauren; Lazaro, Rachael (4 October 2023). "Lucy Letby: Corporate manslaughter probe at Chester hospital". BBC News. Retrieved 4 October 2023.-

Data.event_text: Jaswant Singh Chail, 21, becomes the first person in the UK to be convicted of treason since 1981, after taking a crossbow to Windsor Castle and intending to kill Queen Elizabeth II.

links.text: -"Man who took crossbow to 'kill Queen' being sentenced for treason". BBC News. 5 October 2023. Retrieved 5 October 2023.-

Data.event_text: The Metropolitan Police announce that 21 people arrested during the King's Coronation will face no further charges.

links.text: -Gregory, James (5 October 2023). "King's Coronation: 21 people arrested face no further action, Met says". BBC News. Retrieved 5 October 2023.-

Data.event_text: 2023 Cricket World Cup in India, England competes in the 2023 Cricket World Cup.
56 October  2023 Rutherglen and Hamilton West by-election Labour's Michael Shanks wins, resoundingly defeating the incumbent SNP by a swing of over 20%.

links.text: -Bonar, Megan; Scott, Katy (6 October 2023). "Labour defeats SNP to win Rutherglen and Hamilton West by-election". BBC News. Retrieved 6 October 2023.-

Data.event_text: 7 October  The Criminal Cases Review Commission is to review the conviction of Michael Stone for the 1996 murders of Lin and Megan Russell after serial killer Levi Bellfield is reported to have confessed to the murders.

links.text: -Fuller, Christian (7 October 2023). "Lin and Megan Russell: Michael Stone's murder convictions reviewed". BBC News. Retrieved 7 October 2023.-

Data.event_text: The Foreign Office reports that the departure of British nationals from Gaza will likely take place "in stages over the coming days." The BBC reports that 200 are believed to be in the region.

links.text: -"Britons to leave Gaza in stages, says UK Foreign Office". BBC News. 1 November 2023. Retrieved 1 November 2023.-

Data.event_text: The 2023 AI Safety Summit takes place at Bletchley Park. The UK government announces a "world first agreement" between 28 countries on how to manage the riskiest forms of AI.

links.text: -"UK reveals AI agreement as Elon Musk warns of extinction". BBC News. 1 November 2023. Retrieved 1 November 2023.-
-"Countries agree to safe and responsible development of frontier AI in landmark Bletchley Declaration". Gov.uk. 1 November 2023. Retrieved 1 November 2023.-

Data.event_text: Gail Bradbrook, a co-founder of Extinction Rebellion, is convicted of causing £27,000 of damage to the Department for Transport at a demonstration in 2019.

links.text: -Casciani, Dominic (1 November 2023). "XR founder convicted after four-year legal saga". BBC News. Retrieved 1 November 2023.-

Data.event_text: Figures published by Nationwide Building Society indicate a 0.9% rise in house prices in October, the largest for a year, which Nationwide says was likely due to demand being greater than availability of properties for sale.

Data.event_text: 20 November  The latest stage of the Covid-19 Inquiry hears from Sir Patrick Vallance, Chief Scientific Adviser during the pandemic. He quotes the PM saying "We are too shit to get our act together". He also recalls that Chief Medical Officer Chris Whitty had concerns about the "indirect harms" of lockdown.

Data.event_text: Home Secretary James Cleverly unveils the UK government's five-point plan aimed at reducing legal migration, which includes increasing the minimum salary threshold for a visa from £26,200 to £38,700, and reducing the number of dependants social care workers can bring.

Data.event_text: MPs vote 246242 in favour of an amendment to the Victims and Prisoners Bill requiring the UK government to accelerate plans to establish a body to compensate victims of the NHS infected blood scandal, defeating the government which had not planned to include the measure in the legislation.

links.text: -Nevett, Joshua; Rhoden-Paul, Andre (4 December 2023). "Ministers lose infected blood vote after Tory MPs revolt". BBC News. Retrieved 9 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: Junior doctors in England will stage further strike action after rejecting the latest pay offer, the British Medical Association confirms, with a three-day strike scheduled to begin on 20 December and a six-day strike scheduled to begin on 3 .

links.text: -Triggle, Nick (5 December 2023). "Junior doctors plan nine days of strikes, after talks collapse". BBC News. Retrieved 5 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: The Scottish Prison Service issues new guidelines on transgender prisoners. Trans women who have hurt or threatened women or girls will not be sent to a female prison unless there are "exceptional" circumstances.

links.text: -"Trans women inmates who hurt females to go to male prisons". BBC News. 5 December 2023. Retrieved 5 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: Jesse Darling is announced as the winner of the 2023 Turner Prize.

links.text: -Youngs, Ian (5 December 2023). "Turner Prize: Jesse Darling wins for 'delirious' art using tattered flags and barbed wire". BBC News. Retrieved 5 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: Boris Johnson, who served as prime minister from 2019 to 2022, appears before the COVID-19 inquiry and is questioned by Hugo Keith, counsel to the inquiry. He apologises for the "pain and the loss and the suffering" people experienced during the pandemic. His comments are interrupted by protesters, who are ordered to leave the inquiry room.

links.text: -"I should have twigged Covid risk earlier, admits Boris Johnson". BBC News. 6 December 2023. Retrieved 6 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: Robert Jenrick resigns as immigration minister after the government publishes an emergency Rwanda bill.

links.text: -"Robert Jenrick resigns as immigration minister, MPs told". BBC News. 6 December 2023. Retrieved 6 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: Figures released by Halifax Bank indicate house prices in the UK rose by 0.5% in November 2023.

links.text: -Edser, Nick (7 December 2023). "House prices rise again as mortgage rates ease". BBC News. Retrieved 7 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: Culture Secretary Lucy Frazer confirms the TV licence fee will increase by £10.50 from £159 to £169.50 from 1 April 2024.

links.text: -McIntosh, Steven (7 December 2023). "BBC funding: TV licence fee to rise by £10.50, government says". BBC News. Retrieved 7 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: Serial killer Steve Wright is arrested for the September 1999 murder of Victoria Hall.

links.text: -"Serial killer Steve Wright arrested over 1999 murder of Victoria Hall". BBC News. 7 December 2023. Retrieved 7 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: A letter to MPs from Sir Matthew Rycroft, the Permanent Under-Secretary of State of the Home Office, says that £240m has been paid so far to Rwanda for the Rwanda asylum plan, with a further £50m to be paid in 2024.

links.text: -Rhoden-Paul, Andre (8 December 2023). "UK paid Rwanda an extra £100m for asylum deal". BBC News. Retrieved 8 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: Data from the Moneyfacts Group suggests the average rate on a two-year fixed-term mortgage has fallen below 6% for the first time since June 2023.

links.text: -Peachey, Kevin (8 December 2023). "Average two-year mortgage rate falls below 6%". BBC News. Retrieved 8 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: The Court of Session in Edinburgh rules that the UK government acted lawfully by blocking the Gender Recognition Reform (Scotland) Bill from becoming law, and rejects the Scottish Government's appeal against the decision.

links.text: -"Court says Scottish gender reform block is legal". BBC News. 8 December 2023. Retrieved 8 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: At the Old Bailey, Paul Bryan is sentenced to life imprisonment with a minimum of 24 years for the 1984 murder of Roman Szalajko at the victim's south London home. Bryan assumed the identity of a dead man with the same name, but was traced through a fingerprint match in 2022.

links.text: -Roberts, Ez (8 December 2023). "Paul Bryan: Murderer jailed after 39 years on the run". BBC News. Retrieved 8 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: After footballer Joey Barton suggests that women "should not be talking with any kind of authority" about men's football, Chelsea manager Emma Hayes says women are "routinely used to dealing with systemic misogyny and bullying" in football.

links.text: -"Women used to 'systemic misogyny' in football – Hayes". BBC Sport. 8 December 2023. Retrieved 8 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: Wham!'s Last Christmas tops the singles chart for the fourth time with Mariah Carey's All I Want For Christmas Is You taking the second spot. A week after the death of Shane MacGowan from The Pogues, Fairytale of New York rises to number four.

links.text: -"Wham!, Mariah Carey and The Pogues lead flood of Christmas songs in UK top 40". BBC News. 8 December 2023. Retrieved 9 December 2023.-
-"Official Singles Chart Top 100 on 8/12/2023". Official Charts. 9 December 2023. Retrieved 9 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: Yellow weather warnings are in place for much of the UK as two successive storms, Elin and Fergus, reach the UK from the Atlantic, bringing high winds and heavy rain.

links.text: -Howard, Jacqueline (9 December 2023). "Storm Elin, Storm Fergus duo lash UK with wet and windy weather". BBC News. Retrieved 9 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: The royal family reveal their Christmas card images with King Charles III choosing a photograph from his coronation earlier this year for his second Christmas as monarch. Meanwhile, the Prince and Princess of Wales release a monochrome photograph of them and their children Prince George of Wales, Princess Charlotte of Wales, and Prince Louis of Wales.

links.text: -"Royal Family members reveal family Christmas card images". BBC News. 9 December 2023. Retrieved 10 December 2023.-
-"Royals unveil Christmas cards as Kate and William pose for black and white portrait". The Independent. 10 December 2023. Retrieved 10 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: Lawyers on the right of the Conservative Party describe the new Rwanda legislation as not "sufficiently watertight".

links.text: -"Fresh blow for PM as Tory lawyers warn his Rwanda bill is not fit for purpose". Sky News. 10 December 2023. Retrieved 10 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: In his first broadcast since leaving the post of Immigration Minister, Robert Jenrick tells the BBC Sunak's draft Rwanda law unlikely to work since it is "weak" and will become "bogged down" in legal challenges.

links.text: -"Rwanda asylum bill is too weak to be a deterrent, says Robert Jenrick". BBC News. 10 December 2023. Retrieved 10 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: The skull of a pliosaur is discovered off the coast of Dorset. The 2 m (6 ft 7 in) fossil is said to have roamed the waters 150 million years ago. A David Attenborough documentary is scheduled to air on BBC One on New Year's Day revealing the "risky mission" of unearthing the "T-Rex of the seas".

links.text: -"Pliosaur discovery: Huge sea monster emerges from Dorset cliffs". BBC News. 10 December 2023. Retrieved 10 December 2023.-
-Alberge, Dalya (9 December 2023). "David Attenborough film tells of risky mission to excavate 'T rex of the seas' from Dorset cliff". The Observer. ISSN 0029-7712. Retrieved 10 December 2023.-
-Alberge, Dalya (9 December 2023). "David Attenborough film tells of risky mission to excavate 'T rex of the seas' from Dorset cliff". The Observer. ISSN 0029-7712. Retrieved 10 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: The National Crime Agency (NCA) suggests that street drugs stronger than heroin are linked to the deaths of at least 54 people in the past six months, with 40 more cases awaiting further testing.

links.text: -"Street drugs stronger than heroin linked to 54 deaths in UK". BBC News. 11 December 2023. Retrieved 11 December 2023.-
-Buntajova, Diana (11 December 2023). "Urgent warning as street drugs stronger than heroin linked to 54 deaths in UK". Express.co.uk. Retrieved 11 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: The UK government is offering a £2.5bn financial package for the return of a Stormont Executive, which includes funds to settle public sector disputes and for public services.

links.text: -Campbell, John (11 December 2023). "Stormont: Government offers £2.5bn package for devolution return". BBC News. Retrieved 11 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: The UK government's Safety of Rwanda (Asylum and Immigration) Bill, a piece of emergency legislation to support the Rwanda asylum plan, passes with a majority of 44 as MPs vote 313269 in favour of it.

links.text: -Crerar, Pippa; Quinn, Ben; Walker, Peter (12 December 2023). "Relief for Rishi Sunak as Rwanda bill passes first vote in Commons". The Guardian. Retrieved 12 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: Dorset Police are investigating following the death of an asylum seeker, thought to have taken his own life, on the accommodation barge Bibby Stockholm.

links.text: -Turner, Lauren; Symonds, Tom (12 December 2023). "Bibby Stockholm: Asylum seeker on board barge dies". BBC News. Retrieved 12 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: Mark Drakeford resigns as First minister of Wales after five years in incumbent.

links.text: -"Wales' First Minister Mark Drakeford resigns". BBC News. 13 December 2023. Retrieved 13 December 2023.-

-Morris, Steven (13 December 2023). "Mark Drakeford to step down as Wales first minister". The Guardian. ISSN 0261-3077. Retrieved 13 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: Bernard Looney, the former chief executive of BP, is to forfeit up to £32.4m in salary and benefits after an investigation found he committed "serious misconduct" in failing to disclose relationships with colleagues.

links.text: -Espiner, Tom (13 December 2023). "Ex-BP boss to lose £32m after 'serious misconduct'". BBC News. Retrieved 13 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: The Bank of England keeps interest rates on hold for a third consecutive time at 5.25%.

links.text: -"Interest rates: Too early to speculate about cut, says Bank boss". BBC News. 14 December 2023. Retrieved 14 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: 17-year-old Alex Batty, a boy from Oldham who went missing in 2017 while on holiday in Spain, is reported by French Police to have been found at Revel, a town east of Toulouse in France.

links.text: -Schofield, Hugh; Howard, Jacqueline (14 December 2023). "Alex Batty: Teen from Oldham missing for six years found in France". BBC News. Retrieved 14 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: Three men are convicted of attempted murder after two children (including an 11-year-old girl) were shot while playing on a climbing frame, in Wolverhampton.

links.text: -"Three guilty over Wolverhampton playground shooting". BBC News. 14 December 2023. Retrieved 14 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: Panini Group launches the first sticker album for the Women's Super League.

links.text: -O'Donnell, Aine; Evitts, Jared (14 December 2023). "Panini: First Women's Super League sticker album launches". BBC News. Retrieved 14 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: The High Court rules that Prince Harry was the victim of phone hacking by Mirror Group Newspapers and awards him £140,600 in damages. Separately, the judge rules that Piers Morgan knew about phone hacking  and was involved  while editor of the Daily Mirror.

links.text: -"Harry was victim of hacking by Mirror Group papers, judge rules". BBC News. 15 December 2023. Retrieved 15 December 2023.-
-Topping, Alexandra (15 December 2023). "Prince Harry hails phone-hacking case win as 'great day for truth'". The Guardian. Retrieved 15 December 2023 – via theguardian.com.-

Data.event_text: Muslim convert Edward Little, who planned to kill a Christian preacher at Speaker's Corner in London's Hyde Park, is sentenced to life imprisonment with a minimum term of 16 years following a trial at the Old Bailey.

links.text: -Kelly, James W (15 December 2023). "Speakers' Corner: Edward Little jailed over Hyde Park gun attack plot". BBC News. Retrieved 15 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: Network Rail regional manager Michelle Handforth resigns from her post following a power outage at Ladbroke Grove earlier in the month which left hundreds of train passengers stranded for several hours.

links.text: -Nunis, Vivienne (17 December 2023). "Network Rail manager quits after passengers stranded". BBC News. Retrieved 17 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: Sunak travels to Italy to attend a right-wing rally in Rome, where he discusses his immigration policy and calls for changes to global refugee rules.

links.text: -Squires, Nick (16 December 2023). "Rishi Sunak gets warm welcome at Right-wing political rally in Rome". The Telegraph. Retrieved 16 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: Defence Secretary Grant Shapps confirms that the British destroyer HMS Diamond has shot down a suspected attack drone in the Red Sea, the first time the Royal Navy has shot down an aerial object in anger since 1991.

links.text: -Atkinson, Emily (16 December 2023). "HMS Diamond: British warship shoots down suspected attack drone in Red Sea". BBC News. Retrieved 16 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: Greater Manchester Police confirm that teenager Alex Batty has returned to the UK.

links.text: -"Alex Batty: British teen found in France returns to UK". BBC News. 16 December 2023. Retrieved 16 December 2023.-

Data.event_text: The UK's first spaceport for vertical rocket launches is granted planning approval by the Civil Aviation Authority. Full orbital launches from the site, on the remote Scottish island of Unst, are expected to commence from 2025.
